title: 115_hr2473
content: The Act may be cited as the "Put Trafficking Victims First Act of 2017" and includes a report on safe harbor laws. The "Put Trafficking Victims First Act of 2017" mandates a report on the impact of State safe harbor laws on trafficking victims' re-victimization, recovery, outcomes, and prosecutions of traffickers. It also includes best practices for effective State safe harbor laws that support victims' full recovery without hindering traffickers' prosecutions. SEC. 3. Training for prosecutions of traffickers and support for state services for victims of trafficking. The Victims of Trafficking and Violence Protection Act of 2000 is amended to allocate 5 percent for training and technical assistance in coordination with the Secretary of Health and Human Services, focusing on increasing security and protection for service providers and preventing human trafficking through trauma-informed approaches. The Victims of Trafficking and Violence Protection Act of 2000 is amended to provide services and protections for victims of trafficking, including evidence-based care and mental health services, eligibility for all victims, and training for law enforcement and prosecutors. Officers and prosecutors must ensure that individuals involved in human trafficking are not coerced before making arrests or pressing charges. This includes prosecuting traffickers and those who exploit children for sex, while providing child victims with appropriate legal protections. The curr_chunk discusses protections for child victims of sexual assault, rape, child sexual abuse, or incest, as well as the rights of child victims of trafficking to not be treated as criminals. It also emphasizes the importance of identifying and serving trafficking victims through various methods. The amendments made by subsection (a) regarding services for victims' needs in their communities will take effect on October 1, 2017. SEC. 4. Developing methodologies to assess human trafficking prevalence. Establish an expert working group, including survivors and experts on human trafficking, to identify barriers in data collection on sex and labor trafficking. Utilize existing efforts to address methodological and practical challenges. The Director of the National Institute of Justice will conduct pilot studies to test methodologies for data collection on trafficking. A report will be submitted within 3 years of the enactment of the Act, in consultation with relevant government departments. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, Secretary of Homeland Security, and Director of the Human Smuggling and Trafficking Center will submit a report to Congress on efforts to estimate human trafficking prevalence, determine trends, evaluate policies for victim needs, and analyze trafficking characteristics. The report required by the Secretary of Health and Human Services, Secretary of Homeland Security, and Director of the Human Smuggling and Trafficking Center will analyze the characteristics of trafficking victims in different regions, including age, gender, race, involvement in child welfare or justice systems, number of placements, and type of trafficking. Recommendations will be provided to address the unique vulnerabilities of different victims, and the report will be publicly available on the Department of Justice website. Input from relevant parties will be sought in developing the report. The Director will seek input from various stakeholders, including the United States Advisory Council on Human Trafficking, victims, survivor advocates, and service providers. A survey will be conducted to understand how trafficking victims access services and how they are referred to services. The survey will assess how trafficking victims access services, including referrals by first responders, and estimate the prevalence of human trafficking in the United States. No additional funds are authorized for this section. SEC. 5. REPORT ON PROSECUTORS SEEKING MANDATORY RESTITUTION IN TRAFFICKING CASES. The Attorney General must submit a report to Congress within 1 year of this Act's enactment on efforts to increase mandatory restitution orders and use of asset forfeiture for trafficking victims. The report will include information on DOJ training programs, recommendations for additional training, and an assessment of obstacles preventing restitution orders in human trafficking cases. The report to Congress will assess the effectiveness of asset forfeiture provisions in increasing requests for restitution in trafficking cases and the impact of trauma-informed procedures on mandatory restitution orders for victims of trafficking. The report to Congress will include data on Federal cases related to human trafficking from June 1, 2015, to the present, detailing restitution orders and victim participation in criminal proceedings and witness protection programs. Recommendations for increasing victim participation will also be provided. Sense of Congress encouraging states to adopt protections for victims of trafficking. Congress recognizes and applauds State legislative bodies for adopting protections and services for victims of trafficking. States are encouraged to uphold the basic rights and dignity of survivors, adopt a survivor-centered approach, and implement screening mechanisms for child victims entering various systems. Child victims of trafficking should be connected with appropriate services, including housing and trauma-informed care. They should have access to child welfare services, trauma-informed programming, and legal rights similar to other children who experience sexual abuse. Offenders exploiting child victims of sex trafficking should face serious penalties under sex trafficking laws. Develop a 24-hour emergency response plan for trafficking victims, providing immediate protection and support. Adopt protections for victims, treating them as victims of crime with access to services and legal rights. Trafficking victims have the right to justice, protection, comprehensive care, trauma-informed services, housing, education, job assistance, mentoring, language assistance, substance abuse services, and legal support. Trafficking victims should have convictions related to prostitution and nonviolent offenses vacated if committed as a result of being trafficked, and foreign nationals should be protected from removal or inadmissibility. Trafficking victims should have convictions related to prostitution and nonviolent offenses vacated if committed as a result of being trafficked, and foreign nationals should be protected from removal or inadmissibility, including the right to legal protections and not be treated as criminals, regardless of whether the crime has been reported to law enforcement. The House of Representatives passed the bill on May 23, 2017. Karen L. Haas is the Clerk.
